{{Infobox Fictional Spacecraft | name = ''Intrepid'' class | image = | caption = USS ''Voyager'', NCC-74656 | first = "[[Caretaker (Voyager episode)|Caretaker]]" | last = "[[Endgame (Voyager episode)|Endgame]]" | status = | affiliation = [[United Federation of Planets]]
[[Starfleet]] | launched = 2371 on stardate 48038.5 | decommissioned = | class = | registry = | maxspeed = Warp 9.975 | fighters = | auxcraft = [[Shuttlecraft (Star Trek)|Shuttlecraft]] | armaments = 15 [[Weapons of Star Trek#Phasers|Phaser Array]]s
4 [[Photon torpedo]] Tubes | defense = [[Shields (Star Trek)|Deflector shields]] | propulsion = [[Warp drive (Star Trek)|Warp]], [[Impulse drive|Impulse]] | power = Class 9 Warp Drive | length = 333 meters[http://www.startrek.com/startrek/view/library/ships/article/70517.html STARTREK.COM : Article] | width = | height = | primeref = decks = 15}} The '''''Intrepid''''' class is a fictional [[Starfleet]] [[starship]] class in the [[Star Trek]] universe, the most notable being ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'''s titular [[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|USS ''Voyager'']]. Out of the starships which are the focal point for various television series and films in the Star Trek franchise, the ''Intrepid'' is among the smallest, particularly compared to the [[Starship Enterprise|several vessels named ''Enterprise'']]. In real life, the ''Intrepid'' class was designed by ''Star Trek: Voyager'' production designer Richard D. James and illustrator [[Rick Sternbach]]. ==Technical information== Variable geometry pylons allow ''Voyager'' and other ''Intrepid''-class ships to exceed Warp 5 without damaging subspace. ''Voyager'' was also the first ship to utilize bio-neural computer technology, which makes use of packets of bio-neural gel. The storage medium is [[RNA]]-based, which allows starship computers to accomplish computations almost at the speed of biological entities. The ''Intrepid'' class has the capability to land on a planet's surface, first shown by ''Voyager'' in the episode "[[The 37s]]".{{cite episode| episodelink=The 37s| title=The 37s| series=[[Star Trek: Voyager]]}}{{cite episode| episodelink=Dragon's Teeth (Voyager episode)| title=Dragon's Teeth| series=[[Star Trek: Voyager]]}}{{cite episode| episodelink=Nightingale (Voyager episode)| title=Nightingale| series=[[Star Trek: Voyager]]}} ==Known ''Intrepid''-class starships== Other than ''Voyager'', the only other ''Intrepid''-class ship to be shown on screen has been the USS ''Bellerophon''. The class prototype is the USS ''Intrepid''.{{cite book|title=[[The Star Trek Encyclopedia]]|author=[[Michael Okuda|Okuda, Mike]] and Denise Okuda, with Debbie Mirek|publisher=Pocket Books|isbn=0-671-53609-5|year=1999}} Publicity materials indicate that there were only four ''Intrepid''-class ships planned.{{cite web|url=http://www.startrek.com/startrek/view/library/ships/article/70517.html|publisher=startrek.com|accessdate=2006-11-11|title=USS Voyager}} ;[[USS Intrepid (Star Trek)|USS ''Intrepid'']] (NCC-74600) : Part of Star Fleet Battle Group Omega (ST: Nemesis). ;[[USS Voyager (Star Trek)|USS ''Voyager'']] (NCC-74656) : The primary setting of ''[[Star Trek: Voyager]]'', which features a joint [[Starfleet]]-[[Maquis (Star Trek)|Maquis]] crew lost in the [[Galactic quadrants (Star Trek)#Delta Quadrant|Delta Quadrant]] for seven years. ;USS ''Bellerophon'' (NCC-74705) : Transports [[Vice Admiral (Star Trek)|Vice Admiral]] [[William Ross (Star Trek)|William Ross]], [[Julian Bashir|Dr. Julian Bashir]] and [[Section 31]] operative [[Luther Sloan]] from [[Deep Space Nine (space station)|Deep Space Nine]] to [[Romulus and Remus (Star Trek)|Romulus]] in the ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episode "[[Inter Arma Enim Silent Leges (DS9 episode)|Inter Arma Enim Silent Leges]]". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{memoryalpha|Intrepid class}} {{Star Trek starships}} {{Star Trek}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Intrepid Class Starship}} [[Category:Starfleet ship classes]] [[it:Astronavi di Star Trek#Classe Intrepid]] [[ja:ã¤ã³ãã¬ãããç´]] [[pl:Klasa Intrepid]]
